hedline.hl1: For Fans of the Big Screen (the Really Big Screen)

abstract.p: State-by-state listing of movie drive-ins and related information can be found at Drive-In Theater Web site; photo (S)

block.p: The speaker hanging on a pole has been replaced by an FM broadcast for the dialogue and soundtrack, but drive-in movie theaters still have huge screens, concession stands and children in pajamas in the back of the car.

Fans can find a state-by-state list of drive-ins at the Drive-In Theater Web site (www .driveintheater.com). Some listings -- like that of the Transit Drive-In in Lockport, N.Y., run by the Cohen family for three generations -- include their own history, pictures and a current film schedule.

Fans can find a state-by-state list of drive-ins at the Drive-In Theater Web site (www .driveintheater.com). Some listings -- like that of the Transit Drive-In in Lockport, N.Y., run by the Cohen family for three generations -- include their own history, pictures and a current film schedule.
The site also has a history of drive-ins since the first one opened in 1933, a sampling of animated intermission advertisements (with juggling popcorn and talking hot dogs) and links.
Browser A selection of events and sites on the Web.

TOMORROW, 3 p.m. www.scifi.com/set The premiere of Timothy Hutton in Part One of ''The Lucky Strike,'' a science-fiction audio drama by Kim Stanley Robinson; Part Two will premiere July 28 at 3 p.m. This and several other dramas with actors like Brian Dennehy, Steve Buscemi and Chita Rivera can be heard in streaming audio at the site.

SUNDAY, 10 p.m. www.discoveryhealth.com Chat with Dr. Butch Rosser of the Yale School of Medicine about remote care for patients, or telemedicine. The chat follows the premiere of ''Cybersurgery,'' a documentary, at 9 p.m. on the Discovery Channel.
MONDAY, 2:30 p.m. www.virtuetv.com/music/concerts/petertork /index.html Concert with Peter Tork, a former member of the Monkees, and his band, Shoe Suede Blues, from the Borderline club in London.

TUESDAY, 11:30 a.m. www.excite.com/childrenandmedia Live Webcast of a discussion of children and access to new media by academics and industry executives, from Stanford University, with an address by William E. Kennard, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission.
